so the theory about spike is that I was I was doing sort of some
engagement work for another company and I ran into a protocol called

sort of posts that were going back and forth and there was this whole layer stuff I didn't have anything ready and
and sort of willing to quickly rip off the HTTP stuff so that I could quickly sort of disassemble the protocol
underneath and manipulate the raw it was a binary protocol and so it's really
kind of very difficult to sort of manipulate with the tools that were available and so I started Spike just to handle that

but because so many bugs are so simple you can still get into most machines
with a fuzzer so the goal of Spike you know then was I
mean this is the security space we are looking to find new vulnerabilities um
and and to do that it's useful to be able to quickly reproduce arbitrarily complex protocols and Protocols are
almost all exactly the same luckily for us so this becomes possible
um and also once you have a spike that does something it can do that very quickly
against lots of other protocols and find similar bugs you try to abstract away
as far as possible the bug without taking up forever and that way when you spike a different program maybe you find

enough uh spike is a way to sort of encapsulate your knowledge of the way the protocols
are blocked out most sort of data transfer protocols they have length block length block length block length
block and the lengths and the blocks can be sort of you know interlaced they can be nested they can be you know arranged
in many different orders Spike makes it possible to quickly represent these sort of length the sort of length information
in a way that you can then easily manipulate and it's just very a very simple

up and and then anything that wants to know that information can
